thread.title: No. 23 Duke outlasts Virginia Tech 45-43 in four OTs
thread.title_full: No. 23 Duke outlasts Virginia Tech 45-43 in four OTs | HamptonRoads.com | PilotOnline.com

author: Andy Bitter
title: No. 23 Duke outlasts Virginia Tech 45-43 in four OTs
text:
BLACKSBURG Virginia Tech's first four-overtime game had an unpleasant ending.
Duke quarterback Thomas Sirk improvised on a two-point attempt and bulldozed his way into the end zone to life the Blue Devils to a 45-43 quadruple overtime win against Virginia Tech at Lane Stadium on Saturday.
Virginia Tech went ahead 43-37 in the fourth overtime on a 1-yard touchdown run by Travon McMillian, who had 142 rushing yards and a pair of touchdowns.
But the Hokies’ two-point conversion attempt, which is required after the second overtime, was no good on an incomplete pass.
Duke came right out on its possession, getting a 25-yard touchdown pass from Sirk to Erich Schneider on the first play to tie the game at 37.
Sirk took a shotgun snap on the two-point play, rolled right and didn’t find anyone open. He turned upfield, was met by a Hokies defender before the goal line, but powered his way in.
It’ll be an extremely uphill climb to bowl eligibility from here for the Hokies (3-5, 1-3 ACC), who need to win three of their final four games against Boston College, Georgia Tech, North Carolina and Virginia just to make it to the postseason for a 23rd straight year.
Duke (6-1, 3-0 ACC), which kept pace with Pittsburgh and North Carolina as unbeaten teams atop the Coastal Division, won on its second straight trip to Blacksburg.
Sirk threw for 270 yards and four touchdown passes, adding 109 yards on the ground in what was Duke’s eighth win in its last nine ACC road games.
Hokies quarterback Michael Brewer, who started for the first time since breaking his collarbone in the season opener against Ohio State, returned to the starting lineup and threw for 270 yards and three touchdowns to tight end Bucky Hodges, but it wasn’t enough.
Tech rallied from an 11-point second-half deficit to tie the game at 24 on a 23-yard touchdown pass from Brewer to Hodges with 2:07 left. McMillian’s two-point conversion run tied things up at 24.
Both teams missed late field goals to send the game to overtime.
The teams traded field goals in the first overtime to stay tied at 27.
Tech faced third-and-6 in the second overtime when Brewer hit Hodges in the back of the end zone for an 11-yard touchdown and a 34-27 lead. But Duke answered in three plays when quarterback Sirk hit Anthony Nash for a 4-yard touchdown pass to send the game to a third overtime.
Sirk got leveled on a blitz to start the third overtime but managed to get a pass off that Max McCaffrey made and over-the-shoulder grab on at the Hokies’ 4. But the Blue Devils only came away with a 20-yard field goal by Ross Martin to take a 37-34 lead.
The Hokies didn’t move the ball much on their possession, needing a 40-yard field goal by Joey Slye to send it to a fourth overtime. He nailed it, tying the game at 37.
